questions.question: A patient has sudden loss of vision and there is no fundus glow. There is no history of trauma, what could be the likely cause?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Vitreous hemorrhage Explanation: Vitreous Hemorrhage (VH): Seen as blood floating in the vitreous, occluding the view of the retina. Secondary to proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is a cause of severe vision loss in diabetic patients. Absence of fundus glow is a feature of Vitreous hemorrhage In PDR, fibrovascular tissue lies flat on the retina or attaches to the posterior vitreous, leading to vitreous traction, retinal separation, and vessel rupture. This is the most common cause of VH in adults. Options B, C & D: Acute anterior uveitis, Optic neuritis and Acute congestive glaucoma can also cause sudden loss of vision but there is no loss of fundus glow. Reference: Parsons Diseases of the Eye, Edition 23, page no: 289,290 Yanoff and Duker Ophthalmology,Edition 5, Page 544-551
